abstract.p: Jeff Gordon wins pole position in Kmart 400 auto race (M)

block.p: Jeff Gordon continued his march back to the top of Nascar yesterday and Shawna Robinson officially started her drive into the history books.
Gordon, on a resurgence after a disappointing 2000 season, turned a lap of 188.250 miles an hour around Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn to win the pole for tomorrow's Kmart 400.
Jeff Gordon continued his march back to the top of Nascar yesterday and Shawna Robinson officially started her drive into the history books.
Gordon, on a resurgence after a disappointing 2000 season, turned a lap of 188.250 miles an hour around Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn to win the pole for tomorrow's Kmart 400.
It was his third pole this season and 36th of his career -- three of which have come on this 2-mile oval. That ties him with Alan Kulwicki for the track record.
But Gordon was overshadowed by Robinson, who qualified 32nd. When she takes the green flag tomorrow, Robinson will be the first woman to start a Winston Cup race since 1989.

''This means everything to me,'' she said as her crew from MK Racing embraced her.''Nobody wants it more than I do. This isn't about making one race, this is about the future and racing full-time next year.''
Patty Moise was the last woman to compete on Nascar's top circuit, racing in five events from 1987 to 1989.
Gordon, who put his Chevrolet on the front row for the seventh time this season, said he was excited for Robinson.
''I've always said it doesn't matter if you're a male, a female or what color your skin is -- if you have the talent to be out there, you deserve to be out there,'' Gordon said.

Robinson, who will attempt to make four more Winston Cup races this season before trying a full schedule in 2002, tried hard to shift the focus away from her gender. But Robinson, a 36-year-old mother of two, could not help but stand apart from the 42 men in the field.
''I'm a racer who just happens to be a girl,'' she said. ''I grew up around race tracks and my dad raised me to be competitive.''

While Gordon locked up the pole as soon as he ran his qualifying lap, Robinson had to sweat it out after turning a lap at 185.529 m.p.h. More than an hour went by while she patiently watched the scoring monitor to see how many cars were slower than her Ford.
When it became clear she would make the field, her crew jumped up in joy and her husband, an engine builder for Dale Earnhardt Jr., ran over to hug her.
It was the second time this season Robinson had attempted to make the field. Her first try, at California Speedway in April, ended when she broke a gear on her qualifying lap.
Ricky Rudd, the last man to attempt to qualify, came within two one-thousandths of a second of knocking Gordon off the pole. Rudd ran a lap at 188.240 to earn his Ford the second starting spot.
Mike Skinner will start third in a Chevrolet. Earnhardt Jr. will start seventh.
